teaser: Not even the tooth fairy can escape inflation
contentencoded:
I've got a seven-year-old who's about to lose a tooth — it's just a couple of good wiggles and a twist or two away from coming out. And when it does, I feel pretty safe in guessing that she's going to get about a buck under her pillow.

Turns out, tooth fairies at other houses are a bit more fast and loose with the cash.

A survey by dental insurance company Delta Dental says the national average for American kids is $4.36.

[[{"fid":"286452","view_mode":"default","fields":{"format":"default","field_file_image_alt_text[und][0][value]":"","field_file_image_title_text[und][0][value]":"","field_description[und][0][value]":"","field_description[und][0][format]":"full_html","field_byline_text[und][0][value]":"The Original Tooth Fairy Poll","field_migration_notes[und][0][value]":""},"type":"media","attributes":{"height":294,"width":468,"class":"media-element file-default"}}]]

Not in my house, I'll tell you that.
description: Not even the tooth fairy can escape inflation
title: Tooth fairies reimburse an average of $4 per tooth
